title: Period of SHM - changing pendulum length and mass

content.question: A small sphere of mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is attached to a string of length <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi></math> to form a simple pendulum that moves with a frequency <math alttext="f sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> when it is displaced by a small angle and released from rest. The sphere is removed and replaced with a sphere with mass <math alttext="2 m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and the length of the string is reduced to <math alttext="the fraction l over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. Is the frequency of the pendulum the same in both situations? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the effect of increasing the mass of the sphere counteracts the effect of decreasing the string length.
Yes, because the frequency of the pendulum is independent of the mass of the sphere and the length of string.
No, because the greater sphere mass will cause the pendulum to have a smaller frequency.
No, because the shorter string will cause the pendulum to have a greater frequency.

content.answer: No, because the shorter string will cause the pendulum to have a greater frequency.
